## (a)

Using the ENOE data set (SDEMT first quarter for the period between 2010-2020), we explored the labor market trends for women aged 25â€“65 by computing yearly mean real wages\footnote{All monetary values are expressed in real terms, adjusted to 2015 Mexican CPI levels.}, mean hours worked (both unconditional and conditional), and mean employment rates.

Real wages fell in the first eight years, recovering after 2018, ultimately returning to near their initial levels by the end of the period. Female labor market participation stands at 48-49\% at the beginning of the period and rose to around 53\% by the end. The rising employment rate aligns with broader trends of increasing female participation in Mexico. Conditional hours worked (\textit{i.e.}, for employed women) followed an unstable path, ending at $\sim$38.4 hours per week in 2020, suggesting fluctuations in full-time work intensity. Unconditional hours worked (including non-employed women as zeros) displayed a steady increase, surpassing 20 hours per week by 2020. The volatility in conditional hours worked may indicate shifts between part-time and full-time work, while the growth in unconditional hours underscores the expanding role of women in the labor market. These trends highlight the dynamics of female labor supply, with more women working and, in later years, earning higher real wages on average.

Tables <- function(df1, status){
  df1 <- df1 %>% filter(e_con == status)
  
  final <- matrix(0, 5, 8)
  final <- data.frame(final)
  
  # All
  final[1,c(1,5)] <- c(mean(df1$Employed), mean(df1$Wage/12))
  
  final[1,c(2,6)] <- df1 %>% filter(cs_p13_1 < 4) %>%
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12)) %>% as.numeric()
  
  final[1,c(3,7)] <- df1 %>% filter(cs_p13_1 == 4) %>% 
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12)) %>% as.numeric()
  
  final[1,c(4,8)] <- df1 %>% filter(cs_p13_1 %in% c(7,8,9)) %>% 
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12)) %>% as.numeric()
  
  
  # Less than 35 with young child
  final[2,c(1,5)] <- df1 %>% filter(hj_peq == 1, eda < 35) %>% 
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12)) %>% as.numeric()
  
  final[2,c(2,6)] <- df1 %>% filter(hj_peq == 1, eda < 35, cs_p13_1 < 4) %>% 
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[2,c(3,7)] <- df1 %>% filter(hj_peq == 1, eda < 35, cs_p13_1 == 4) %>% 
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[2,c(4,8)] <- df1 %>% filter(hj_peq == 1, eda < 35,cs_p13_1 %in% c(7,8,9)) %>%
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  
  # Less than 35 with no child
  final[3,c(1,5)] <- df1 %>% filter(hj_peq == 0, eda < 35) %>% 
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[3,c(2,6)] <- df1 %>% filter(hj_peq == 0, eda < 35,cs_p13_1 < 4) %>%
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[3,c(3,7)] <- df1 %>% filter(hj_peq == 0, eda < 35,cs_p13_1 == 4) %>%
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[3,c(4,8)] <- df1 %>% filter(hj_peq == 0, eda < 35,cs_p13_1 %in% c(7,8,9)) %>%
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  
  # Edad: 35-54
  final[4,c(1,5)] <- df1 %>% filter(eda >= 35, eda<=54) %>% summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[4,c(2,6)] <- df1 %>% filter(eda >= 35, eda<=54,cs_p13_1 < 4) %>% 
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[4,c(3,7)] <- df1 %>% filter(eda >= 35, eda<=54,cs_p13_1 == 4) %>%
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[4,c(4,8)] <- df1 %>% filter(eda >= 35, eda<=54,cs_p13_1 %in% c(7,8,9)) %>%
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  
  # Edad: 55+
  final[5,c(1,5)] <- df1 %>% filter(eda >= 55) %>% 
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[5,c(2,6)] <- df1 %>% filter(eda >= 55,cs_p13_1 < 4) %>% 
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[5,c(3,7)] <- df1 %>% filter(eda >= 55,cs_p13_1 == 4) %>%
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  final[5,c(4,8)] <- df1 %>% filter(eda >= 55,cs_p13_1 %in% c(7,8,9)) %>%
    summarise(mean(Employed), mean(Wage/12))%>% as.numeric()
  
  rownames(final) <- c("All", "Less 35 - Young Chld",
                       "Less 35 - No Chld", "35-54",
                       "55+")
  
  colnames(final) <- c("All", "Less HS", "HS", "College+",
                       "All - W", "Less HS - W", "HS - W", "College+ - W")  
  return(final)
}

As expected, employment rate and earnings are lower for women with low educational levels. Single women exhibit the highest labor force participation, with employment rates around 70\% overall, peaking at 52\% for those under 55. In contrast, married women show significantly lower employment rates (42\% overall), particularly among older groups (close to 30\% for those 55+). Cohabiting women fall between these two groups, with employment rates around 46\% overall. The presence of children reduces employment probabilities, especially for partnered women under 35.  employment rate drops from 49\% (no small children) to 46\% (with children under 16).

Wage patterns mirror the employment trends. Single women earn substantially more (2703.54 pesos weekly on average) than their married (1623.60 pesos) and cohabiting (1655.12 pesos) counterparts. The wage gap persists across age groups, with prime-age (35-54) single women earning nearly double what married women of the same age earn. Children appear to negatively impact earnings, particularly for married women under 35, whose weekly wages are about 23\% lower if they have children. Older women (55+) experience a sharp decline in wages across all marital statuses (which might be due, in part, to retirement), though single women maintain a relative advantage. 

These patterns suggest that marriage and child-bearing remain significant barriers to women's labor market participation and earnings in Mexico. The substantial gaps between single and partnered women likely reflect both cultural norms around caregiving responsibilities and potential labor market discrimination against mothers. The particularly relative low employment and wages of older women indicate additional challenges in workforce retention later in life.

We calculated women's share of housework hours within heterosexual couples. Our sample included working-age women who were either household heads or spouses of heads, matched with their most likely male partners (either household heads or spouses) from the same household. We excluded same-sex couples.

The female share of housework ($R$) was computed using, 
$$R = \frac{H_w}{H_w + H_s}$$
in which $H_w$ represents woman's weekly housework hours and $H_s$ denotes her male spouse's weekly housework hours.

The ratio in Figure \ref{} provides a measure of the relative domestic burden on women within partnered households, either married or cohabiting.

            day_care   = sum(day_care, na.rm = T),
            day_exp    = sum(day_exp, na.rm = T))


PobH <- PobEni %>% group_by(folioviv, foliohog) %>%
  summarise(age_hhead = edad[which(parentesco == 101)],
            age_hspouse = first(edad[parentesco %in% c(201,202)]),
            married = edo_conyug[which(parentesco == 101)])




ConcEni <- ConcEni %>% left_join(VivEni, by = c("folioviv"))

ConcEni <- ConcEni %>% left_join(GasH, by = c("folioviv",
                                              "foliohog"))

ConcEni <- ConcEni %>% left_join(PobH, by = c("folioviv",
                                              "foliohog"))


ConcEni <- ConcEni %>% 
  filter(clase_hog == 2)


ConcEni <- ConcEni %>% mutate(Income = ing_cor - ingtrab,
                              Food =  ali_dentro + ali_fuera,
                              Transportation = transporte,
                              HealthService = salud,
                              Utilities = pred_cons + agua + energia,
                              Education = educacion,
                              HouseKeeping = cuidados,
                              Rent = ifelse(homeownership == 0, alquiler, estim_alqu),
                              Insurance = health_ins + other_ins,
                              Health_ins = health_ins,
                              Home_ins = other_ins,
                              Childc = day_care + child_care)



vars_to_summarise <- c("Income", "Food", "Transportation", "HealthService", "Utilities", 
                       "Education", "HouseKeeping", "Rent", "Insurance", "Health_ins", 
                       "Home_ins", "Childc")



tabela_resumo <- ConcEni %>%
  filter(married %in% c(1, 2)) %>%
  group_by(married) %>%
  summarise(
    across(all_of(vars_to_summarise),
           list(Mean = ~mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
                Median = ~median(.x, na.rm = TRUE)))
  )
